msIdentifier.collection: The Library of the Dropsie College for Hebrew and Cognate Learning

body.p:
Dear Sir. Having recently gotten hold of the last issue of
the “Occident” I was much surprised on finding in it an article
from Mr E. Marcussohn denying his ever having abjured
Judaism. Now it may be proposed to state what I know of this
gentleman, as the Editor of the Occident seems to solicit information
concerning him.

Mr Marcussohn was introduced to me at my house by Rev
Mr Bonhomme (a gentleman long and favorably known.)
He appeared a little awkward from his want of a ready use of
the English language, for this he apologized, and expressed a
desire to enter upon the study of it. Thereupon I proposed that
he should instruct me in Hebrew and I would in turn teach him
English. In order to carry out this arrangement he was to visit
me at a certain period hour every morning (That is when his
engagements or mine did not otherwise prevent). For several
weeks he continued to come, when together we would read the
Old and New Testaments frequently stoping while reading to
comment upon some passage. He appeared greatly interested in
the New Testament especially with those portions found in the
first chapters of Mark, embracing the Savior's sermon on the
Mount. He observed the most profound reverance in speaking
of Christ. He acknowledged the importance of a Mediator in our
approaches to the Father. Spoke of the ineficiency of the law to justify
the sinner. Told me that he prayed to God to pardon his sins, and that he
felt that he had received pardon. I spoke plainly with him touching
the witness of the spirit, & the inward peace consequent upon the
forgiveness of sins. He remarked that he felt that he had received this
witness & this peace. I felt anxious for Mr M. to be placed beyond all doubt
in regard to his spiritual change, & hence I often conversed with him
upon the subject of the new birth—or scripture religion. He expressed great
dissatisfaction with the duties laid upon him as Teacher of the Jewish faith,
Complained of his brethren, their want of enlightenment & so on. Said he
was receiving from them $500.00 a year as a salary, that they paid him at
fixed times, said that one installment would be due him in a few weeks,

but that he felt that he could not remain with them up to that time as it
would be acting the part of the hypocrite. This he mentioned more than once,
Of course I could but sympathize with him, in what I conceived to be the honest
struglings of conscience.

On the 5th July according to my best recollection, he made his appearance at my
house, greatly agitated. Said that he had given up his church & had declared
in favor of Christianity. He stated at the same time that he need money, & had
no means of paying it, as the Jews whom he had been serving would no doubt
withhold that portion of his salary which was due him. Seeing him in
this unpleasant dilemma, I advanced him $70 which he said would
be sufficient to pay him out of debt. He now left his boarding house,
and moved his trunks to my house and lived with me. I noticed in him
a perfect conformity to Gentile customs.

When he first visited me he would not take a drink of water except
with his hat on, if it was not at hand, he would leave his seat and go in
search of it. After he came to my house to live, he gave up this custom, indeed
he gave it up before.

Again he sat at my table and ate whatever I did, and what without any apparent scruple
I was a little surprised when he asked me the loan of my razor, and stated that
he had never put a razor upon his face, but that he had been accustomed to clip
his beard with a kind of scissors. He handled the razor very awkwardly but
made out to sh?. Since then I think he has used this instrument altogether
especially during his Conversion to Christianity

In regard to his church preferances, he said that they were with the Methodist, that he
believed in their doctrines, & desired to unite with them. The time when I was to receive
him by baptism into the church was appointed but owing to some circumstance it was
defered. In the meantime Rev. Mr Davis & myself had an interview upon the subject of
his uniting with the church, Our claims upon him were about equal, & we agreed that
neither of us would receive him, or in any way influence him to become a member of our
respective communions, but that we would leave him to make up deliberately his own
mind & decide for himself.

After this I was compelled to be absent from my station for several days and consequently
procured for Mr M. another home, which was at the house of one of my members, where he was
well cared for and fed. He showed while here no anti-swine disposition but

ate this kind of flesh with a gusto. Since I disposed of Mr M. as
alluded to, I have not seen him up to the present time. The particulars
touching his history from thence to his setting out for Charleston S. C.
Rev. Mr Davis can give you. (We both honestly endeavored to benefit a
man who shewd himself in our way for instruction & guidance, if
we have been deceived it is not any guilt of ours. We feel acquited
before God and at the bar of our own consciences. The religion which
we profess teaches us to forgive those who wrong us. So did our divine
Master before us, & so do we. In conclusion I humbly recommend friend
Marcussohn if he has never known Christ to seek him with all his
heart, & when he has truly found him he will never disown him, but
like his noble countryman & brother after the flesh Paul he can say
“God forbid that I should glory save in the cross of Jesus Christ” &c.
Yours truly, C. D. Oliver Pastor of M. E.
